ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My writing skills improved immensely and it was a terrific survey of a variety of important American texts!

This course helped me gain insight not only on foundational American literature, but also how literature functions in America  as a newer country, we are in many ways defined by our literature. The books on the curriculum were a great survey of American literature.
I widened my knowledge of the American Literature canon.
I have developed the ability to close read, engage in literary discourse, analyze literary criticisms, and write academic papers.
The course helped me develop a clearer and more concise writing style, as well as deepen my literary analysis skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: interesting material]
weaknesses: pacing (had to rush at the end), assignments took a long time to be returned
This course functions exactly as it should. Professor Kelley approached each work thoughtfully and helped us through the difficult texts. It was both accessible and stimulating.
The canon of texts could be widened - maybe some plays etc.

I really enjoyed the diverse selections of literary works that we read and how the discussion was structured. I felt very comfortable contributing to the discourse because of the welcoming environment that Dr. Kelley cultivated in the classroom. I definitely learned a lot from preparing for class discussions and writing the papers.

The discussion posts and class discussions were helpful towards deepening our understanding of and insight into the class readings. However, it would be helpful if there were more graded assignments for which we could receive feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Especially with Prof Kelley! I loved the syllabus, the class discussions, and the papers. My understanding of American history and literary analysis improved so much.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are genuinely interested in literature enough to talk/analyze it. I will say, this course is probably also well suited to obtain a WR credit.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in a basic literature course that allows for a sampling of the American literary tradition(s). Its also kind of fun to read Moby Dick, because I dont think I would have ever read it were I not forced to.
Yes - the poetry was very enjoyable

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. You will get to read canonical American novels from a diverse range of authors. The questions this class raises make you think deeply about what America is and how it was shaped. You will also get to see historic events in America from different perspectives, which I really enjoyed.
Yes, definitely. The professor is incredibly fair, empathetic, and most of all, very committed to the material and her students understanding of it.
